repnme.cdata!:
Chile - Social Protection Sector Adjustment
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability highly likely, and institutional development
            impacts substantial. Lessons address four main issues: 1)
            this adjustment operation specifically focused on poverty
            reducing policies, in contrast to recent adjustment
            operations in the social sectors, i.e., multi-sector
            programmatic variety. Due to its nature and poverty focus,
            and the changes required by the new policies, project
            results are likely to have beneficial external spill-over,
            effects on the quality of public services in the social
            sectors, benefiting groups beyond just the poor. 2) At the
            Government's request, the instrument selected was the
            Deferred Draw Down Option (DDO), prepared as such at the
            early stages of project identification. This presented the
            advantage that the Bank support was for an already underway
            reform program, thus with substantial Government commitment
            ensured, which in turn, did reduce the risks associated with
            a reform program. 3) The reduced conditionality in a single
            tranche is a positive feature that reflects in this case,
            the nature of the DDO instrument, while one other special
            feature associated with a DDO is that the commitment fee is
            only applied 60 days after the loan agreement is signed,
            and, since all conditions are met before Board presentation,
            there is a strong incentive for fast disbursements, a
            contributing factor to this operation's success. 4)
            Finally, it is highlighted that the link with the Technical
            Assistance Loan will ensure continued Bank involvement,
            regardless of the DDO's quick disbursements, and will
            also help support the sustainability of the reform program.

repnme.cdata!:
Chile - Social Protection Adjustment Loan
            Project : exercise of drawdown  - full compliance

abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Protection Sector Adjustment
            Loan supports the efforts of the Government of Chile to: (a)
            improve the access of the poorest households to the social
            protection system; and (b) increase the effectiveness of
            this system in alleviating extreme poverty. As part of the
            financial terms for the Loan, the Borrower selected a
            Deferred Drawdown Option.  The Government's request to
            exercise a drawdown is granted, based on the country's
            overall performance and implementation of the Program, as
            detailed in this report.

5087392.majtheme: Public sector governance,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Social protection and risk management,Rule of law

repnme.cdata!:
Chile - Social Protection Sector Adjustment
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Protection Sector Adjustment
            Loan Project will support government actions in five key
            areas: a) maintenance of a satisfactory macroeconomic
            framework, consistent with sustaining economic growth to
            reduce poverty; b) reform implementation of the
            country's poverty reduction, and social protection
            policies, to minimize exclusion, thus creating greater
            access to social protection, and broader social services for
            the neediest households (Chile Solidario initiative); c)
            increased efficiency of social policy, through improved
            targeting, and better use of information, through the
            integration, and exchange of public and private household
            data, relevant to social policy, into a national information
            system; d) strengthening regular monitoring, and impact
            evaluation of social programs, and policies; and, e)
            enhanced sustainability of reforms regarding poverty
            reduction, and social protection policies, through clearly
            defined roles, and responsibilities between the central
            government, municipal authorities, and civil society. While
            the risks to this program are considered modest, and
            Chile's excellent track record in economic management,
            program implementation, and transparency outweighs potential
            risks, several areas of implementation could prove difficult
            for the Government, in particular closing the employment gap
            among the neediest households, and ensuring the appropriate
            targeting of Chile Solidario program, which includes
            historically excluded groups, such as indigenous
            populations, and, in addition, promoting greater local
            government and civil society participation may prove difficult.
